title: Nelson's Column: Dominic Cummings' street urchin look isn't chic. It's a cheek
text:

How you dress does not affect how you think. But it does say something about what you think of others.

Boris Johnson’s oddball sidekick Dominic Cummings is arguably Britain’s most powerful man, the puppeteer pulling the PM’s strings.

The former Vote Leave supremo favours a scruffy, dishevelled, dragged through a hedge fund backwards look.

With his crumpled shirts, ripped jeans and scuffed trainers he should be kickflipping in a skateboard park not rocking up for work at No10.

Sometimes he tops off this ensemble with a hoodie, but mostly with an armless, padded, quilted jerkin known as a gilet which is French for vest.

(Image: Peter Summers)

I appreciate Cummings would rather be found dead in a ditch than be mistaken for a traditional civil servant.

But cultivating overgrown street urchin chic is less a fashion statement and more a statement of disdain, not just for the government he serves but by extension the rest of us.

Someone must have forcibly shoehorned him into the suit he wore for Irish talks on Thursday. No wonder he looked downcast.

Ok, I too sometimes sport jeans and a t-shirt in Parliament - but only on non-sitting days.

And I don’t turn up in a tie anymore because they are no longer required since Commons Speaker John Bercow ruled we could dispense with them.

(Image: PA)

But if I do a TV show in which a male presenter is likely to wear one then I will, too. As a guest I respect the host’s dress code. It’s just good manners.

Cummings is No10’s unelected guest.

And it’s plain rude to dress down to suit himself when everyone else is dressed to suit the stylish surroundings.

Otherwise you might as well put the seat of government in a garden shed.

I remember when Cummings worked for Michael Gove he was more aggressive than persuasive.

(Image: PRU/AFP via Getty Images)

Which made me less likely to give his boss favourable publicity.

Now Cummings has really powerful figures to browbeat.

Last week he was suspected of releasing No10’s rambling, 800 word Brexit report. His authorship is not denied.

It rubbished Ireland’s Leo Varadkar, Germany’s Angela Merkel and France’s Emmanuel Macron , and threatened punishment for EU countries backing a Brexit delay.

(Image: CLEMENS BILAN/EPA-EFE/REX)

It concluded with: “Parliament is as popular as the clap.”

So there you have it.

The writer no one cast a vote for despises representative democracy, its leaders, foreign leaders, foreign countries and is obsessed with dumping Europe whatever the cost or the ordinary folk it would hurt.

Surely it’s a national scandal to have someone at the very top of government who drips contempt like rainwater off a gilet.

Our drugs laws have gone to pot

(Image: MDM)

Last year 1,584 children were dragged into court for cannabis possession. Fourteen million Brits have used the drug, 2.4 million in the past 12 months alone.

The radical think tank Radix and former Lib Dem Health minister Sir Norman Lamb argue legal regulation is the answer.

Norman claims it would lead to reduced use, fewer unsafe high-potency drugs, less crime, and £1billion in tax revenues.

Labour’s David Lammy and Tory Jonathan Djanogly say cannabis should be a child protection issue not a criminal one. Many senior police officers agree.

(Image: BBC)

I would go further. Drug laws in this country are outdated and don’t work.

Portugal decriminalised possession of small amounts of all drugs in 2001 and now has one of the lowest rates of drug-induced death in Europe.

Fears it would become an international haven for druggies were unfounded.

Better for those at risk of addiction to fall into the caring arms of health professionals than the long arm of the law.

The bog paper minister is on a roll

Bog roll minister Simon Hart was as enthusiastic as an Andrex puppy as he flushed claims of a no-deal shortage of toilet tissue down the pan.

The Implementation minister (for that is his official title) is implementing plans to ensure our supplies of toilet paper are uninterrupted.

He said: “The Government will prioritise the flow of goods at the border while continuing to take a risk-based approach to controls and checks.”

I take that to mean that as super-soft presents no obvious terrorist threat or is a commodity favoured by smugglers it would not be delayed by fussy paperwork.

Brexit Countdown Days til we leave EU 0 Days 0 Hours 0 minutes 0 Seconds

Hart added that this would “minimise additional friction.” That’s a relief.

There would be much additional friction if we had to go back to that abrasive tracing paper many of us can remember having to use during our schooldays.

So raise a glass to Simon. Cheers, mate. And bottoms up.

Dom could lose another seat

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

Rebel Tory Dominic Grieve still sits in his usual Commons tearoom seat.

Brexiteer Tories want him out.

Andrew Bridgen says: “We must avoid him infecting others with a dose of Europhilia.”

Some MP is being a silly sausage

(Image: PA)

House of Commons wifi is patchy, which makes connecting to it a nightmare.

But it’s entertaining to try because it throws up all the phones you can pair with.

So come on. Own up.

Which of you MPs goes by the name German Sausage Boy?

And fess up, Pink Duck.

Gavers gets an education

(Image: PA)

MPs were puzzled by Gavin Williamson copping Education in Boris Johnson’s Cabinet shuffle.

He was sacked as Defence Secretary by Theresa May for allegedly leaking security secrets which he stoutly denies.

But Cabinet Secretary Mark Sedwill told the PM he shouldn’t come back.

Boris protested: “But I promised him a job.”

Education was the compromise solution.

Because now Williamson is the one Cabinet minister not required to attend security briefings.
description:
Does the way those who govern us dress make a difference? Sunday Mirror Political Editor Nigel Nelson
thinks so
